_comment: SCENARIO 8: Circular Goals - Complex Motion Pattern Tracking
_description: Goals orbit in circles around fixed center points at 0.5 rad/s (about 28 degrees per second). This creates a more complex and challenging motion pattern than straight-line translation. The circular motion means goal positions are continuously changing direction, which tests whether predictive reallocation can anticipate non-linear goal trajectories.
_expected_outcome: Predictive reallocation with proper prediction horizon should significantly outperform reactive methods here, since anticipating circular motion allows better assignment optimization
_key_challenge: Goals continuously change velocity direction. Your prediction horizon becomes crucial - too short and you can't anticipate the curve, too long and predictions become less accurate
_paper_contribution: Shows the method works even with complex non-linear goal motion, extending beyond simple translation scenarios
_real_world_analogy: Think of coordinating multiple drones to track moving vehicles that are turning, or robots following objects on a conveyor belt with curves
